Makhsatoy is engaged in this business together with her husband. Slowly the number of cows increased and with them, her clients started asking for more and more. With an endless list of requests she has finally decided to increase the number of livestock she keeps, and for this reason she is requesting a loan. You can be an important part of the growth of Makhsatoy’s business.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married. She has a 9-year-old child. Olga is an entrepreneur from Nikopol where she works in two different marketplaces – Venetsiya and Pervomaiskyi. She sells knitwear and underwear items. Olga is very prudent. She started her business 6 years ago and worked hard to give it a solid standing. Presently, Olga has 70,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her income amounts to 17,000 Grivnyas.   

Olga is seeking a 15,800 Grivnya loan to purchase additional merchandise. She offers this type of inventory at reasonable prices. It is always in high demand. Olga is hoping to continue growing her venture in the future.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital.

loans.name: Felma

texts.en:
Felma L. is from the village of Malibacsan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old and married. Felma owns and operates a business providing motorcycle services to local community members. Felma has been involved in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Felma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan, her third, of 7000 PHP which will be used to provide additional capital for her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for better service

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kotognontala, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 36 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Zagnenabougou, sous préfecture de Fana,  Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens professionnels et de parenté et font le commerce de céréales, d’ustensiles de cuisine et de condiments alimentaires.                                                                                      
Les femmes du groupe Kotognontala sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 sacs de céréales et des condiments destinés  à la restauration.                                                                         
Elles s’approvisionnent en céréales avec les grossistes de la place et les condiments sont achetés dans les foires voisines. Elles effectuent leurs ventes sur place et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35 000F CFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Kotognontala group are all married, have an average age of 36 years old, an average of four children and all live in extended traditional families in Zagnenabougou, the subprefecture of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through their businesses and via relatives, and they trade in cereals, kitchenware and food condiments. The women in the Kotognontala group are on their fourth group loan, which will be used to buy four bags of cereals and condiments for catering purposes. They get their supplies of cereals from local wholesalers, and their condiments are purchased at neighboring fairs. They sell locally and in surrounding fairs, on a retail basis for cash and on credit, to a customer base made up of women and men. They are expecting to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA, which will be used to cover expenses relating to health, food and school fees; the balance will be reinvested in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals and condiments

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de quatre femmes toutes mariées dans des ménages monogames avec en moyenne 39 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent le quartier Bougoufiè de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté.
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et de diversifier les articles à vendre, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec  qui, elles sont à leur 5ème  prêt de groupe, après avoir bien remboursé les  quatre précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 11 pièces de pagne wax, un rouleau de bazin, des produits de teinture et 6 douzaines de tasses de marque super. 
Les bazins sont d’abord teintés en fonction de la commande ou de la créativité de l’artiste pour pouvoir attirer les clients. 
Elles s’approvisionnent du Burkina Faso, au grand marché de Ségou  et parfois à Bamako. Les marchandises sont revendues au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 39 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour assurer les soins de santé et de scolarisation des enfants. 
Elles ont pour ambitions de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of four women, who are all married and living in monogomous households. They average 39 years old and have an average of five children each. They live in the Bougoufiè district of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and met through neighbors and relatives. With a view to increasing their business and diversifying the items they sell, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and they are now on their fifth group loan with the institution, having repaid the four previous loans without problem. This new loan will be used to buy 11 pieces of "pagne-wax" (a West African term for highly decorative and colourful fabric), a roll of damask fabric, dying products and six dozen top brand cups. The damask fabric is firstly dyed in line with the order or according to the artist's creativity in order to attract clients. They get their supplies in Burkina Faso, at the large market in Ségou and sometimes in Bamako. The goods are retailed for cash and on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. They are counting on making an average monthly profit of 39,000 FCFA, which will be used to cover health costs and their childrens' schooling. Their ambition is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Clara C. is from the village of Linconcomonan, Gingoog City. She is 49 years old. Clara is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Clara owns and operates a business venture running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Clara has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Clara joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clara is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Clara from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Alia

texts.en:
Alia A. is currently in the business of selling fish and charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to stock fish to sell. Alia is 25 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school yet.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock fish to sell.

loans.name: Arnulfo

texts.es:
El señor Arnulfo O. T. de profesion constructor de obra posee varios años en el rubro, vive en casa propia en el barrio Jardin de la cuidad de Encarnación, esta casado con la señora Estelvina Torres y tiene 3 hijos aun menores y en edad escolar.
El tiene trabajo constante ya que es constructor muy bueno y sus trabajos son muy bien realizados.
El solicita el préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción para hacer refracciones en su casa. Quiere reparar el techo con tejas nuevas, rebocar y pintar paredes.
texts.en:
Sr. Arnulfo O. T. is a professional builder with many years of experience. He lives in his own home in the neighborhood of Jardin in the city of Encarnación. He is married to Sra. Estelvina Torres and has three young children who are in school.

Arnulfo always has a steady flow of business since he is known as an excellent builder who produces quality work. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy construction materials for making repairs to his house. He wants to replace the tiles on the roof and plaster and paint the walls.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sand, cement, roofing tiles, and paint

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita T. is from the village of Parabba, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 36 years old. Teresita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Jeffrey

texts.en:
Jeffrey R. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. He is 34 years old. Jeffrey is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jeffrey owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from catching and selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Jeffrey has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jeffrey joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeffrey has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to buy fishing nets. Jeffrey is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to repair the pumpboat that he uses in catching fish. Jeffrey also wants to buy another, bigger pumpboat than he has now. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Jeffrey from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his pumpboat

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional second hand cloth items to sell

loans.name: Nicasio Antonio

texts.es: Nicasio Antonio tiene 66 años, el se dedica a la actividad económica de una pulpería. Por lo que no es la primera vez que tiene financiamientos por haber comprado los productos. El ofrece la venta de productos básicos como arroz, azúcar, aceite, frijoles, golosinas y pan, ya que su pulpería está ubicada en su vivienda y así ofrecer gran variedad de productos para sus clientes. Solicita el financiamiento para capital de trabajo para comprar los productos necesarios y ofrecer una gran variedad. Siempre sueña con mejorar cada día más su actividad.
texts.en:
Nicasio Antonio is 66 years old, and he owns a small grocery store. This is not the first time he has sought financing to purchase products. He offers for sale basic products like rice, sugar, oil, beans, sweets, and bread. Since his store is located in his home, he can offer a good variety of products to his clients. He seeks this loan to invest in the purchase of the products necessary to offer a good variety. He dreams of improving his business every day.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Khristine

texts.en:
Khristine D. is from the village of Brgy. Escoting, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 25 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Khristine owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Khristine has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Khristine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Khristine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Khristine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
